Name: Teacher retention reporting requirement and task force.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to a teacher retention reporting requirement and task force

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Education

Summary: This bill would require the Department of Education (DOE) to report data to the Council concerning teacher retention and turnover. This bill would also require DOE to post data on each school’s website concerning teacher retention at each school. A task force would then be convened to analyze this data and issue a report with recommendations to address the issue. The task force would dissolve after it issues the report, but the reporting requirement would remain in place indefinitely.

\pard\ltrpar\fi720\sl480\slmult1\qj Section 1. Title 21-A of the administrative code of the city of New York is amended by adding a new chapter 29 to read as follows: \par
\pard\ltrpar\fi720\sl480\slmult1\qc\cf1\ul\caps Chapter 29\par
Teacher Retention\par

\pard\ltrpar\fi720\sl480\slmult1\qj\'a7 21-1000. \cf0 Definitions. For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms have the following meanings:\ulnone  \par
\ul Career development. The term \ldblquote career development\rdblquote  means professional development opportunities for teachers provided by the department, including but not limited to the teacher career pathways programs and the graduate scholarship program. \par
Non-teaching staff member. The term \ldblquote non-teaching staff member\rdblquote  \cf1 means a school-based department employee who does not have a teacher title.\par
School survey. The term \ldblquote school survey\rdblquote  means the survey administered annually by the department to teachers, students and parents to collect information about each school\rquote s ability to support student success.  \par
Teacher. The term \ldblquote teacher\rdblquote  means a school-based department employee who has a teacher title.\par
Type of classroom. The term \ldblquote type of classroom\rdblquote  means the setting in which a teacher is placed, including but not limited to general education, special education, integrated co-teaching classrooms and any other types of classrooms, which may include additional services or supplementary aids.\par
Unique employee identification. The term \ldblquote unique employee identification\rdblquote  means a sequentially assigned indicator that represents an individual department employee. \par
\'a7 21-1001. Reporting. a. Annual report. No later than November 30 of the year following the effective date of this chapter and annually thereafter, the department shall submit to the speaker of the council information for the prior school year pursuant to subdivisions c, d and e of this section. The first report provided pursuant to this section shall include data from the 1999-2000 school year through the most recent completed school year, to the extent practicable. \par
b. School level reports. Beginning November 30 of the year following the effective date of this section and annually thereafter, the department shall post on each school\rquote s website:\par
1. The information for teachers at such school required by paragraphs 1 through 5 of subdivision c of this section; and\par
2. Such school\rquote s average numbers for paragraphs 4 and 5 of subdivision c of this section. \par
c. Teacher tenure data. Each row in this dataset shall be an individual teacher and, to the extent practicable, the corresponding columns shall include but not be limited to: \par
1. Unique employee identification;\par
2. School year;\par
3. Date of hire; \par
4. Length of time teaching in total; \par
5. Length of time teaching at school for reported school year; \par
6. Gender identity; \par
7. Race; \par
8. Ethnicity;\par
9. Age;\par
10. Title; \par
11. Provisional status; \par
12. Highest level of education; \par
13. Area(s) of teaching certification;\par
14. Any career development the teacher has attained;\par
15. Salary;\par
16. School name; \par
17. School district borough number;\par
18. Grade(s) taught;\par
19. Subject(s) taught;\par
20. Language(s) of instruction;\par
21. Type of classroom(s);\par
22. Percentage of white students;\par
23. Percentage of black students;\par
24. Percentage of hispanic students; \par
25. Percentage of asian students;\par
26. Percentage of students in multiple race categories not otherwise specified; \par
27. Percentage of students in economic need as determined by the department; \par
28. Percentage of students with individualized education plans; \par
29. Percentage of students in temporary housing; \par
30. Average number of students in classroom;\par
31. Number of student removals;\par
32. Number of students sent to principal; \par
33. Number of students sent to superintendent; \par
34. Number of students expelled; \par
35. Number of students with removals or suspensions; \par
36. Number of students with multiple removals and/or suspensions;\par
37. Number of students transported by EMS;\par
38. Number of students with removals or suspensions resulting from incidents involving NYPD; \par
39. Average student academic grade; \par
40. Average student personal behaviors grade;\par
41. Whether teacher experienced emotional trauma while working; and\par
42. Whether teacher experienced physical trauma while working. \par
d. School survey data. Each row in this dataset shall be an individual teacher and, to the extent practicable, the corresponding columns shall include but not be limited to the teacher\rquote s unique employee identification, school year, school name, school district borough number and the teacher\rquote s responses to the school survey questions. If, after the effective date of this subchapter, the survey questions administered to teachers change, the department shall continue to report teacher responses to questions in the areas of effective leadership, safety, program coherence, peer support for academic work and supportive environment. This dataset shall include for each teacher the following school survey responses:\par
1. Students in class listen carefully when teacher gives directions;\par
2. Students in class follow the rules in class; \par
3. Students in class do their work when they are supposed to;\par
4. Students in class feel it is important to come to school every day; \par
5. Students in class feel it is important to pay attention in class;\par
6. Students in class think doing homework is important; \par
7. Students in class try hard to get good grades;\par
8. Students are safe outside and around school;\par
9.  Students are safe traveling between home and school;\par
10. Students are safe in the hallways, bathrooms, locker rooms, and cafeteria of school;\par
11. Students are safe in class and/or classes; \par
12. Discipline is applied to students fairly in school; \par
13. Principal/school leader makes clear to staff expectations for meeting instructional goals;\par
14. Principal/school leader communicates a clear vision for the school; \par
15. Principal/school leader understands how children learn;\par
16. Principal/school leader sets high standards for student learning; \par
17. Principal/school leader sets clear expectations for teachers about implementing what they have learned in professional development; \par
18. Principal/school leader carefully tracks student academic progress;\par
19. Principal/school leader knows what is going on in their classroom;\par
20. Principal/school leader participates in instructional planning with teams of teachers;\par
21. When the school starts a new program, there is follow-up to make sure the program is working; \par
22. It is clear how all of the programs offered are connected to school\rquote s instructional vision; and\par
23. School curriculum, instruction and learning materials are all well-coordinated across different grade levels.\par
e. Non-teaching staff member data. Each row in the dataset shall be an individual non-teaching staff member and the corresponding columns shall include but not be limited to:\par
1. Unique employee identification;\par
2. School year;\par
3. School name; \par
4. School district borough number; \par
5. Date of hire; \par
6. Length of time employed in this area in total; \par
7. Length of time employed at school for reported school year; \par
8. Gender identity; \par
9. Race; \par
10. Ethnicity;\par
11. Age;\par
12. Title; and\par
13. Provisional status. \par
\'a7 21-1002.\cf0  Task force. a. There shall be a task force convened for the purpose of improving retention of department teachers. \par
b. Composition. The task force shall consist of at least 13 members as follows:\par
1. The mayor, or the mayor\rquote s designee;\par
2. The speaker of the council, or the speaker\rquote s designee;\par
3. The chancellor, or the chancellor\rquote s designee;\par
4. Five members appointed by the mayor, including one member who is a member of a union representing teachers, one member who is a member of a union representing principals, one member who is an expert in \cf1 the field of study that examines education and the creation of effective teacher development, one member who is a behavioral scientist who studies learning and assessment and one member who is an expert in assessment, evaluation, testing and other aspects of educational measurement; and\cf0\ulnone\par
\cf1\ul 5. Five members appointed by the speaker of the council,\cf0  including one member who is a member of a union representing teachers, one member who is a member of a union representing principals, one member who is an expert in \cf1 the field of study that examines education and the creation of effective teacher development, one member who is a behavioral scientist who studies learning and assessment and one member who is an expert in assessment, evaluation, testing and other aspects of educational measurement.\par
c. Member appointment. All members shall be appointed no later than 30 days after the department submits its first report pursuant to subdivision a of section 21-1001. No member shall be removed except for cause by the appointing authority. In the event of a vacancy during the term of an appointed member, a successor shall be selected in the same manner as the original appointment.\par
d. Terms of membership. Members of the task force shall not be required to take or file oaths of office before serving on the task force. Each member of the task force shall serve without compensation.\par
e. Task force meeting and hearing requirements. The task force shall meet no later than 45 days after the department submits its first report pursuant to subdivision a of section 21-1001. The task force shall meet no less than monthly. The task force shall hold at least one public hearing every quarter to solicit public comment and recommendations about improving retention of department teachers.\par
f. Report. The task force shall submit a report of its findings and recommendations to the mayor and the speaker of the council no later than one year after its first meeting. The report shall also be posted to the department\rquote s website. The report shall include but not be limited to a review of \cf0 the datasets submitted pursuant to section 21-1001, recommendations to improve teacher retention and suggestions of additional data needed to analyze teacher turnover. \cf1 The task force shall dissolve upon submission of the report required by this subdivision.\cf0\par
\cf1 g. This section expires and is deemed repealed after the submission of the report required by subdivision f of this section.\ulnone\par
\'a7 2. This local law takes effect immediately after it becomes law.  \par
